awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant:   Coarticulation and the phonetics of fingerspelling
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to study how signers produce American Sign Language (ASL) fingerspelling. Studying fingerspelling provides opportunities to find contextual and time conditioned variation in handshape that are relatively limited in signing. This work builds on phonological systems of sign language production, but with a detailed focus on the specific aspects that make up handshapes in ASL. Quantitative measurements of video and motion capture data will be used to analyze contextually based handshape variation in ASL fingerspelling. In this process a large fingerspelling corpus will be created. Such a corpus will be widely available for future research, and will be particularly useful for automatic sign language recognition. 

Findings from this work will contribute to knowledge of how human languages are produced. Handshape in ASL has the power to inform our understanding of articulatory gestures in a way that is difficult to study in the vocal tract. Specifically, individual articulators have a number of different configurations that are active and nonactive. This is unlike many spoken language articulators, which frequently have a single configuration when active, and another when nonactive. Because sign language articulators are not inside the body, precise measurements to analyze the differences between the configurations of articulators when active and nonactive can be obtained more easily than for speech articulators. These findings will further theories of variation cross-linguistically, and more importantly, cross-modally; linguists can better understand what properties in language production are inherent to language, and what properties are modality specific. Additionally, this research will further the understanding of handshape in sign phonology.
 
This work has a number of broader impacts. First, automatic recognition of sign languages requires knowledge of handshape variation.  This work establishes general norms for fingerspelling in native ASL users. Having quantitative norms of specific features of fingerspelling allows for the development of metrics and tests for what types of productions fall outside of the range of typical signers. Second, there has been research showing a correlation between fingerspelling ability and literacy. Understanding basic phonetic facts about the production of fingerspelling will allow for more detailed future work on the perception of fingerspelling. Furthermore, understanding how fingerspelling is produced and perceived will enable the study of this correlation in more detail.

por.por_cntn:
Fingerspelling allows English words to be represented in American Sign Language (ASL) via a series of handshapes, one for every letter of the alphabet. These sequences are produced rapidly and fluidly. It is just one part of ASL, but it is an important part, for several reasons.  As some new words enter ASL via fingerspelling, it is a living laboratory where we can see many of the phonetic processes of the language as a whole. Because the 26 handshape targets are well described, fingerspelling allows us to analyze the factors that influence variation in production—the signer, as well as the phonetic and phonological context. Because it is a part of ASL where the signed word for each letter of the alphabet consists of handshape and orientation of the hand it is a perfect place to begin sign language recognition in ASL. Handshape/orientation of the hand are the main properties that vary, since typically the location does not change, and except for two letters -J- and -Z-, the movement is a function of the transition between one handshape and the next.  It is an important contact phenomenon between English and ASL, it's possibilties for linking English and ASL vocabulary, it has important implications for signing Deaf children as they are learning to read. It is therefore extremely important in ASL acquisition.

In this dissertation project, Keane’s objectives were to:

1) Collect a large corpus of fingerspelled forms, so that his analyses would be based on a large number of data points;

2) Identify factors at work in variation: linguistic context, signer, overall speed, and the proportion of time spent in holding the target handshapes vs. the transitions between them;

3) Provide essential information about fingerspelling to develop an system of automatic recognition of fingerspelled words across signers;

4) Improve techniques for the collection of motion capture data along side regular video data;

5) Develop a semiautomatic method for annotating fingerspelled data;

6) Develop a Hidden Markov Model (HMM) for detecting fingerspelled sequences in the data already collected;

7) Begin to use the analyses of fingerspelled forms produced as stimuli in perception studies; and

8) Disseminate his results.

In his dissertation and subsequent work with colleagues, Keane has accomplished all of these objectives. At the University of Chicago there is the largest set of fingerspelled data of ASL anywhere. Keane’s semi-automatic annotation techniques have been developed for and used in his dissertation, and they have also been used in several additional studies. We have now developed a way to align regular video and motion capture data so that they can be analyzed together. The analyses of these data have resulted in 12 publications or conference presentations, which include the use of the production forms as stimuli to be used to understand how fingerspelling is perceived and learned by several groups of ASL learners. Four different open-source software packages were created to help test and represent linguistic theories, process data, and further help researchers doing similar work in the future. Finally, work done on this project is helping current and future projects understand the importance of fingerspelling, and the phonetics and phonology of American Sign Language, broadly speaking.
